title: hawick-pump-track-given-go-ahead
story: PLANS for a pound, pump track in Hawick have been given the go-ahead by council planners.The pump track, which will feature ramps, jumps and banked corners for bikes, will be situated on the site of the former tennis courts in Wilton Lodge Park, and is being pushed forward by the Hawick Community Pump Track group.The group has already received pound, from Scottish Borders Council, which also owns the former tennis courts, and is currently fundraising to make up the extra cash.Ben Wilson, the grouprsquos secretary, said: ldquoThe committee are absolutely enthralled about the news this being a pretty big milestone.ldquoWersquove put in a lot of work over the past years and itrsquos great when you get news of successful effort, wersquove still a fair way to go but itrsquos one step closer.ldquoThis planning permission has opened up opportunities to tap into certain funds that need planning as a requirement.ldquoThe facility will be available to use from kids on balance bikes all the way to as old as you like.ldquoThe facility itself comprises of two tracks. One smaller track for kids on balance bikes and people new to the sport, which encourages progression in skills enabling them to move onto the larger track.ldquoEven the larger track has progression from learners to elite riders, offering something for all.ldquoThe benefits to the community of the town are great especially the often forgotten about teenagers.ldquoThis facility offers a place to engage in a sport improving social skills alongside health and well-being.The group has plans to install floodlights for the track, but this will need separate planning permission, and a bat survey is due to be carried out in May which will likely decide the fate of the application.Mr Wilson added that although this is a major milestone for the group, they havenrsquot set an opening date: ldquoIn terms of opening I couldnrsquot commit to a date at this stage as it is all dependant on successful funding.ldquoWhen we have everything in place there will be plenty of time to publicise and create a hype.

title: earlston-family-hopes-to-help-other-grieving-parents-with-joes-toes
story: A DEVASTATED Earlston family is hoping to ease the pain for other grieving parents by undertaking a series of spring and summer challenges.And all proceeds from their fundraising will go towards creating lasting mementoes for mums and dads to remember their lost babies.Last February Keith and Marie Briggs welcomed identical twins into the world - eight weeks early.Thomas Joseph Briggs, known as Tommy, was born first, shortly before his twin brother Joseph, known as Joe, who was sadly stillborn as a result of twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome.Tommy spent five weeks in hospital and was cared for both in the Special Care Baby Unit at Borders General Hospital and the Simpsons Neonatal Intensive Care Unitat the Royal Infirmary in Edinburgh.During those weeks before Tommy was finally allowed home, the Briggs family was supported by the Childrenrsquos Hospices Across ScotlandDiana nurse Evelyn Rodger.Evelyn has remained an invaluable support ever since.Part of her role as a Diana Nurse is to provide bereavement support and to help parents find ways to create lasting memories of their babies.Marie told us: ldquoEvelyn is a compassionate, kind, gentle woman who is incredibly knowledgeable in bereavement care and we feel privileged that she was there to support us in making cherished memories with Joe and with saying goodbye with no regrets.ldquoAs part of the memory making process, we askedshe would be able to help us take D casts of Joersquos feet."Evelyn was more than willing to help us in any way she could."Joersquos cast is now one of our most cherished possessions and to be able to physically touch, hold, see, something that was exactly his is so very precious.ldquoOur little Joe has given us, and now other families, so much without even being here."He never drew breath but he has changed us forever. He has reminded us all of how precious and fragile le can be."Every day is a challenge but he has already shown us that we have a strength within us inidually and as a family that can move mountains."May he always know how much he was wished for, longed for, prayed for and wanted.In Scotland, more than , children and young people live with le-shortening conditions and CHAS provides its hospice services nationwide for many of the babies, children and young people from Rachel House in Kinross and Robin House in Balloch.A D cast service is available within the CHAS hospices, but the Joes Toes project will take the mementoes into neonatal units - providing an opportunity for many more parents to make precious lasting memories following the death of their baby.All funds raised by the Joes Toes project will allow CHAS to purchase materials required to make the D baby hand and foot-casts.In the coming months, the Briggs familyrsquos fundraising group will tackle the -mile Tour de Lauder cycling challenge, which will include an extra  miles to make it to Borders General Hospital, the Edinburgh half marathon, the Great North Run, the Loch Ness Marathon and also hosting a ladies cocktail night in the summer.,params: .pushThey are currently halfway towards raising their pound, target.Fiona Leslie, who is the community fundraiser at CHAS, added: ldquoAlong with Marie and Evelyn, we are currently designing a beautul box that families will be able to put their castings in to transport home and keep safe."We canrsquot thank Marie, Keith, their family and friends enough for taking on this awesome summer of fundraisers for this particularly special project."The funds they raise and this idea in itself will help bring comfort to so many families. Itrsquos a lovely legacy for their little boy.Anyone wishing to sponsor the Briggs family can go to https:give.everydayhero uk joe-s-toes

title: sbc-defends-non-disclosure-of-damning-lowood-report
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has defended not disclosing a damning report which condemned plans for developing Lowood Estate, ahead of a decision to splash out more than pound million was approved.The report, produced by the property consultancy firm Jones Lang LaSalle , determined that the Lowood portion of the Tweedbank masterplan is ldquounviable and undeliverable and that ldquoit is quite clear that what is proposed is over-development of the site.The damning report, commissioned by Middlemede Properties Ltd, who own the Upper Pavilion fishing beat adjacent to the proposed Lowood development, was presented to SBC chiefs months before the council purchased the land for pound. million in December .Once costs of borrowing and other fees have been factored in, the purchase will cost SBC around pound million and forms parts of its wider plan to address a regional housing shortfall of some  units.The Lowood site has been earmarked for around  properties, however the JLL report suggests that the development is unlikely to yield any financial gain.The report claims: ldquoOur conclusion is that there would be insufficient revenue to generate either a developerrsquos profit or a positive land value.In addition to questioning the economic viability of the development, the JLL report raises concerns that ldquothe level of development and infrastructure proposed would seriously harm the environment and the River Tweed interests from a physical and amenity perspective.Stuart Bell, SBC Councillor for Tweeddale East, told the Borderthat he nor other voting councillors were not given access to the report prior to rubber-stamping the planned purchase of the land.He said: ldquoI was unaware of this report and its conclusions when the decision was taken by Scottish Borders Council to purchase the Lowood Estate.ldquoI think that many other Borders councillors were similarly in ignorance of it which is worrying given the signicance of its conclusions that the Lowood proposal is over-development and not commercially viable.ldquoThis does seem strange to me when the report is dated March  and I understand it was passed to council officers.ldquoGiven the potential signicance of the analysis and conclusions I have written to SBC officers asking for clarication on why this report was not brought immediately to the attention of councillors.Scottish Borders Council has defended both the report not being tabled and also the purchase of the picturesque estate.A spokesperson said: ldquoThe JLL report was produced as a response to the Housing Supplementary Guidance document which the council was required to produce as part of the Local Development Plan.ldquoHowever, it was not submitted to the council until after the expiry of the public consultation period and after the Guidance had been considered and approved by the council in August .,params: .pushldquoThere was therefore no opportunity for it to be presented to Councillors when they agreed to allocate Lowood for development.ldquoThe viability of development at Lowood Estate was thoroughly reviewed in a series of subsequent technical reports that formed the basis of the recommendations made to councillors in private on May , .ldquoThe report considered by Members in March  contained detailed analysis including a thorough consideration of market conditions which went signicantly beyond the scope of the JLL report.ldquoWe remain satisfied that the basis of the recommendations to and decisions made by councillors on May  is robust and includes a comprehensive review of all relevant issues contained in the JLL report.ldquoWe believe this vital site is capable of delivering an estimated  jobs, as part of a wider masterplan for Tweedbank which could create over  jobs for the Scottish Borders.

title: selkirk-couples-dazzling-success-with-innovative-sunglasses
story: BEING dazzled by the sun is now a thing of the past thanks to new light adapting sunglasses from Borders business.KomodoPro sunglasses can adapt to the sunrsquos rays in less than a second and are being targeted at game shooters as an essential piece of kit.Mick and Anna Bell are currently in their second year of selling the sunglasses.The couple currently live in the Ettrick Valley after moving up from London to escape the corporate world.They now run three businesses, the most notable of which is Bloke Fly Rods, which reach customers worldwide from their office in Selkirk.Mick and Anna have attended ious trade shows across the UK to promote KomodoPro and have sold out at each one in the last  months.The Scottish Game Fair, held at Scone Palace, was the most successful show for the pair in .The fair was held over three days, but by pm on the first day the KomodoPro dhelf was emptied and a hunt for more stock took place.The next event the couple will be attending is the Northern Shooting Show in Harrogate on May  and , where they intend to continue their success from the past year.Currently they have exclusive UK distribution for the Japanese innovation, which retail at pound per pair.Mick Bell told us: ldquoKomodoPro is a revolutionary new product which is perfect for game shooting.ldquoWhat makes the sunglasses unique is that they are so fast they make a stepless change between light and dark."You canrsquot see it happening.ldquoLast year was great for us and now we are predicting more success in the coming year."Standard photochromic sunglasses take up to  seconds to adapt to light compared to KomodoPro which take an astonishing one-tenth of a second, making them stand out against competitors.The sunglasses use a solar powered sensor to detect the level of UV light.And each lens has a wire and a microchip that assesses how much UV inflection is taken in by the sunglasses.For more information on KomodoPro you can visit www.komodopro

title: pet-of-the-week
story: This weeks Pet Of The Week, from Borders Pet Rescue, is five-year-old Pal.The charity told us: "Pal came in to us as his owner was struggling to cope with him. He needs to be the only pet in a home without children but he is a happy boy so will make a great companion for someone. Poor Pal has already had at least three homes before coming in to our care, so his next home needs to be his forever home."Pal hasnrsquot had much basic training although he does have pretty good recall and he is clever, so picks up on training easily. He is looking for a home where he can get this much-needed training and he definitely needs an active home where he can get plenty of exercise and stimulation. His favourite thing is chasing a tennis ball!"If you would like to offer Pal his forever home, please email info@borderspetrescue.org for an application."

title: local-authority-top-brass-are-rolling-in-it
story: THE pay of Scottish Borders Councilrsquos top executives has been revealed.In total, the councilrsquos six highest earning executives were paid more than half a million pounds, with the councilrsquos chief executive Tracey Logan taking home pound, in  .The local authorityrsquos next highest paid employee, SB Caresrsquo managing director Philip Barr, was paid pound,, while services director Rob Dickson received remuneration of pound,.Donna Manson, who was the service director for children and young people before moving to Highland Council to become a chief executive, was paid pound,, and chief financial officer David Robertson was paid pound,.Finally, Martin Joyce, the service director of assets and infrastructure, was paid pound, for his services.However, the chief executive and other directors agreed to a voluntary pay freeze in  in order to help with council cutbacks.The figures have been released by the TaxPayersrsquo Alliance, a right wing pressure group that campaigns for a low tax society, as part of its annual townhall rich list.John OrsquoConnell, the chief executive of the TaxPayersrsquo Alliance, said: ldquoThe average council tax bill has gone up by more than pound over the last twenty years and spending has gone through the roof.ldquoDisappointingly, many local authorities are now responding to financial reality through further tax rises and reducing services rather than scaling back top pay.ldquoDespite many in the public sector facing a much-needed pay freeze to help bring the public finances under control, many town hall bosses are continuing to pocket huge remuneration packages, with staggering pay-outs for those leaving their jobs.ldquoThere are talented people in the public sector who are trying to deliver more for less, but the sheer scale of these packages raise serious questions about efficiency and priorities.A Scottish Borders Council spokesperson said: ldquoScottish Borders Council has reduced the number of officers paid salaries of over pound, in recent years, from four in   to the current number of two.ldquoSalary levels at Scottish Borders Council are set by reference to national agreements and reflect the scale and responsibility associated with the management of a complex public sector organisation with gross annual turnover of poundm.ldquoThe council is well aware of the challenging financial times we are faced with. This is why we have over several years made decisions to help protect our frontline services and our staff.The spokesperson added that Tracey Loganrsquos salary is lower than the majority of other local authority chief executives in Scotland, with  out of the  Scottish chief executives drawing a higher annual salary.

title: 28-year-old-admits-causing-disturbances-in-galashiels-and-walkerburn
story: A -year-old man has been banned from a Galashiels pub until the outcome of his case.Neil Brown appeared from custody at Selkirk Sherf Court and pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner in the Harrow Inn in High Street on Wednesday, April .He also admitted behaving in a threatening or abusive manner in Tweedholm Avenue, Walkerburn, on Friday, April , as well as attempting to self-harm and attempting to assault a police officer.Sentence was deferred until May  for background reports.He was granted bail to an address in Edinburgh with the special conditions not to enter the Harrow Inn or Tweedholm Avenue as well as not contacting three named family members.

title: greggs-submits-plans-to-develop-galashiels-eyesore
story: GREGGS has submitted an application to develop a Galashiels eyesore.The bakery chain is hoping to open a new store at the former Ozkans Grill takeaway in Market Street.Andsuccessful, it would have an outdoor seating area for customers.Over the last few months, the town centre site has been targeted by vandals.Since the takeaway closed, windows have been smashed and the store front covered with graffiti.But proposals submitted to Scottish Borders Council this week show Greggs is hoping to give the unit a facelt and would install four tables and  chairs in the outdoor seating area.The chain, which was launched in Newcastle in , has around , shops nationwide including one in Channel Street.However, it is not yet clearthat would remain openthe plans were given the go-ahead.The firm also has stores in Hawick, Kelso and Peebles.The Borderhas contacted Greggs for comment.

title: housebuilder-apologises-after-admitting-responsibility-for-defective-peebles-homes
story: ONE of the countrys largest housebuilding firms has finally issued an apology to Peebles homeowners.For over two years seven families living on the Kingsmeadows development have been battling with the builders over defects caused by crumbling mortar.Earlier this year Taylor Wimpey acknowledged, as part of its full year results statement, concerns regarding mortar durability and added that a "robust technical solution" to fix the problem had been identied.Work has already started on the affected  properties and this week, the company offered an apology.A Taylor Wimpey spokesperson told the Peeblesshire News: ldquoWe sincerely apologise to the affected homeowners for the issues that they have experienced within some homes at our Kingsmeadow development in Peebles."While a signicant number of houses on the development are unaffected by mortar issues, a robust technical solution to fix the durability of the mortar has been identied, which is supported by our appointed structural engineer, an independent review by the Scottish Borders Council, and the National House Building Council."We have a clear plan in place to remediate affected homes and works have already begun on the development.Problems first emerged with houses on the Kingsmeadows development in .Scottish Borders Councils building standards officers were contacted as well as Taylor Wimpey.The developer bought back several properties from householders after faults were identied.Non-disclosure agreements prevented the families from discussing the issues.In  more concerns were raised with the local authority over public safety on the development.And Tracey Logan, chief executive of Scottish Borders Council, called a meeting with Taylor Wimpey bosses where it was agreed for an independent structural engineer to carry out surveys.Although no structural issues were identied during the surveys of randomly selected properties the developer acknowledged there were problems with mortar on some houses.And towards the end of last year they sent out letters offering to carry out remedial action.A spokesperson for Scottish Borders Council told us: "The first public safety concerns were raised with the council in late ."In response to these concerns, the Chief Executive requested a meeting with Taylor Wimpey to investigate the concerns."At this meeting, it was agreed that an independent structural engineer would be commissioned to carry out structural surveys in a number of randomly selected properties."This was carried out in summer ."The council did not have an official role in this process, but it was considered important to provide an independent opinion on the situation to ensure that any concerns were identied and addressed effectively and consider whether there was any public safety risk."The report identied no structural issues with the inspected houses and was satisfied with Taylor Wimpeyrsquos proposed remedial action to repair potential defects,required, andthe owners wished to take up this offer, which we understand a number of residents have."A BBC investigations team identied that the Peebles housing development was one of  across the country where inferior mortar had been used.Sheila Chalmers and her husband recruited their own structural engineers to carry out assessments on their Peebles home - and both contradicted a Taylor Wimpey survey identying extensive repairs were required.And, along with six other families from the Kingsmeadows development, Mr and Mrs Chalmers continued to campaign for the developer to admit responsibility and fix the structural problems.Mrs Chalmers told the BBC: "These developers, these companies, cannot be allowed to continue the destruction of peoples lives with building shoddy homes."Somebody has to stand up and show them that they cannot get away with it."

title: local-politicians-react-to-brexit-extension
story: LOCAL politicians have reacted to the news that the Brexit withdrawal deadline has been delayed until October .The extension was approved by EU leaders following protracted talks in Brussels last night, averting the immediate threat of the UK leaving without a deal.Under the extension agreement the UK is now dutybound to hold European elections in May, although the country could still exit the EU before OctoberTheresa May can secure parliamentary support for her withdrawal agreement.David Mundell, Scottish Secretary and MP for Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale, was pleased with the extension but warned of hard work ahead. He said: ldquoFirst and foremost, Irsquom pleased we have avoided leaving the EU without a deal.ldquoMy top priority all along has been to avoid a no-deal Brexit and the disruption it would cause.ldquoDelaying Brexit is not ideal, but Parliament has so far failed to support a withdrawal deal that would allow us to leave in an orderly fashion.ldquoWe have to continue working to achieve that.ldquoDonald Tusk, the President of the European Council, has urged us not to waste this extra time. He is right.ldquoWe have avoided no-deal, but we still have a lot of work to do.MSP for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, Christine Grahame, has demanded that Theresa May holds a second EU referendum and reaffirmed her desire for Scottish independence.She said: ldquoThis extension will come as a relief to those who feared us crashing out without a deal on Friday, however the key question is what is done during this extension - Scotlandrsquos interests must be protected.ldquoTheresa May must use this time to hold a fresh EU referendum with the option to Remain on the ballot paper.ldquoThe Borders did not vote for Brexit and should not be forced to accept a Brexit deal put together by Labour and the Tories ndash parties that have ignored Scotlandrsquos voice and interests every step of the way.ldquoIf Labour helps the Tories push through their plans to leave the Single Market, ending freedom of movement - which will cost jobs and hit public services in the Borders and where - they will not be forgiven at the ballot box in Scotland.ldquoThe UK governmentrsquos Brexit fiasco shows clearly that the Borders and indeed Scotlandrsquos interests are best protected through independence.

title: melrose-replaced-by-st-boswells-in-2019-sunday-times-best-places-list
story: MELROSE has lost its crown as the best place to live in Scotland.But it has been replaced in the Sunday Times top ten list by neighbouring village St Boswells.Ten locations in Scotland have been named among the Best Places to Live in the UK by The Sunday Times, with Dundee coming out on top.The Sunday Times Best Places to Live guide, including the overall winner, is published on Sunday, April .The supplement assesses a wide range of factors, from employment, schools and broadband speed to culture, community spirit and local shops, in order to compile the definitive top locations to live.Up to date house prices provided by Habito and TwentyCi, are also used as well as the knowledge of The Sunday Timesrsquos expert .The judges combine the hard data with their own on-the-ground experience and insight to ensure the chosen locations truly are places where everyone can thrive.Scotlandrsquos sunniest city, Dundee, has made it to the top spot for the nation this year.Along with North Berwick, it is one of two locations within Scotland thatfrom last yearrsquos The Sunday Times Best Places to Live guide.Edinburgh has two locations on the  list.Leith, Edinburghrsquos old port, has been recognised for its cutting-edge creativity and culinary scene, and Stockbridge, on the fringe of the New Town, is praised for its beautul properties and village atmosphere, and pretty walks along the Water of Leith.In the Highlands, Port Appin, in Argyll, features thanks to breathtaking scenery that provided fabulous opportunities for walking, cycling and sailing, and welcoming community spirit.The scenery is even more breathtaking on Mull, the only island on this yearrsquos list.Best known as the setting for childrenrsquos TV favourite Balamory, the judges described it as the perfect Goldilocks option: not too remote, not too busy, and perfectly Scottish from its white-sand beaches to its gorse-covered slopes and Munro-sized peak, Ben More.Other selected locations include Glasgowrsquos trendy Finnieston district, as well as the attractive commuter towns of Kilmacolm and Killearn.Last yearrsquos winner, Melrose, narrowly misses out, with its place taken by its Borders neighbour St Boswells, home of the award-winning bookshop and deli Mainstreet Trading.Helen Davies, The Sunday Times Home editor said: "Finding our very own best place to live now feels more important than ever, for our wellbeing and wealth, happiness and health."Wherever you are on the property ladder The Sunday Times has championed  locations across the UK, and crowned one lucky winner, that we think is a great place to make a home."This year we were looking for community spirit along with convenience and culture."There is so much going on around the country, and so many great places that the choice was a hard one."Daniel Hegarty, Founder and CEO at Habito, the online mortgage broker said: "We know there are many reasons, beyond house prices, why people live where they live in Scotland. But, regardless of location, getting a mortgage can be the most hellish part of buying."Habito exists to make mortgages easier - whether thatrsquos for a historic apartment in Leith, Edinburgh, a cottage with a view in St Boswell, or a family home in Dundee.

title: borders-businesses-out-in-force-for-tourism-summit
story: MORE than  businesses gathered in Peebles last week for the Scottish Borders Spring Tourism Conference.Held at the Hydro hotel, groups were able to hear from a range of speakers ndash including Professor John Lennon from the Moffatt Centre, Stephen Leckie from Crieff Hydro and Matthew Jackson from National Geographic Traveller.And a number of tourism masterclasses on brand building, story-telling and delivering great customer service took place.Will Haegeland, chairman on the Scottish Borders Tourism Partnership told us: ldquoTodayrsquos event has demonstrated that there is a genuine passion for developing our visitor economy and putting the Scottish Borders firmly on the tourism map.ldquoWe closed the conference with an industry plea for a continued need for enthusiasm, energy and passion for the Borders.ldquoWe are also looking for people who would be interested in joining the Destination Management Marketing Organisation board.ldquoIf thatrsquos you, then we will be putting in place an application process but in the first instance we look forward to hearing from businesses.The event also saw the launch of the lsquoScotland Starts Herersquo promotional tourism app.The software has been developed by the MBTAG , headed up by project manager Gemma Reid.

title: historic-borders-church-set-for-new-life-as-a-theatre
story: IT has been described as one of the most important buildings in the Borders.And the historic Polwarth Church is about to be brought back to le as a theatre.The current building, which dates back to  but incorporates sections from as far back as the mid-th century, has been closed as a place of worship since .It was later sold by the Church of Scotland to neighbouring Marchmont Estates and has remained vacant ever since.But plans by Marchmont Farms Limited to re-open the building as both a church and a theatre have been approved by Scottish Borders Council.A spokesman for the local authority said: "Polwarth Church would be repurposed from its existing use a church to become a building that could be used as a church, music hall and theatre."Whilst the planning service acknowledge that it may be unusual to find a music hall or theatre in a rural location such as this, it would repurpose a building that would otherwise lay vacant - thus having the potential to fall into a dilapidated state."The proposed development would repurpose and provide security to a listed building that is of great signicance, safeguarding it for some time to come."Polwarth Churchs intended use would be directly related to leisure and recreational purposes."The principle of development is considered to be acceptable."It is believed there has been a Christian Church on the site since at least the tenth century.But it was following the Reformation that it entered the history books.Sir Patrick Hume, who was a strict Presbyterian and brought up at Polwarth, studied law and represented his country Parliament.But the defender of the Covenanters was forced into hiding after being implicated in the Rye House Plot to murder Charles II.For four weeks he hid in the vaults of Polwarth Church - being supplied food by his daughter Grizell - until making his escape to Europe.He lived under cover, with a price on his head, in Utrecht assuming the alias of a surgeon called Dr Wallace.It was some four years later in  that Sir Patrick Hume ed to Scotland with William of Orange.His estates were restored to him and in  became Lord Chancellor, and honoured the next year with the title Earl of Marchmont.Hume financed the rebuilding of Polwarth Church in .The approved plans for the A listed building will see minor interior and exterior alterations carried out.The Lairds door to the south elevation will be reinstated and a dilapidated lean-to store to the north will be removed.Internally, the pulpit and alter rail will be fitted onto casters to allow for flexibility in use of the space to adapt from a church to theatre and musical venue.The plans also include a new outbuilding which will be used for toilet, changing and ticketing facilities.The local authority spokesman added: "The proposed external alterations to the church would be of an appropriate scale, character and appearance, which would improve the churchs condition and overall appearance within the locality."

title: 30-year-old-admonished-for-causing-ae-disturbance
story: A GALASHIELS woman who caused a disturbance at Borders General Hospital on Christmas Day in  has been admonished at Selkirk Sherf Court.Cassie McDermott, of Gala Park, previously had sentence deferred for six months for good behaviour.The -year-old had admitted behaving in a threatening or abusive manner in the hospitals casualty ward.

title: horse-cruelty-trial-delayed-until-july
story: THE trial of a Selkirk man accused of causing unnecessary suffering to horses in his care has been put off until the summer.Nick Mill, of Ettrickhaugh Road, previously denied the two charges at the towns sherf court and a trial was fixed for April .But at an intermediate hearing it was stated that pressure of business on that day with other trials meant it was unlikely to go ahead.As a result a new trial date has been set for July .The -year-old has been charged under the Animal Health and Welfare Scotland Act.It is alleged he failed to get proper veterinary care for a horse that was emaciated and another which had an infected tail.The offences are said to have happened at the Lauriston Stables in Ettrickhaugh Road between April  and July  last year.

title: leaderfoot-roadworks-finish-ahead-of-schedule
story: ROADWORKS on the Leaderfoot Bridge between Melrose and Earlston have been removed two weeks ahead of schedule.The traffic management was due to last for three weeks but was removed after just  days on Thursday, April .The work was being conducted as part of the final stages of construction of a pound million pipeline designed to provide the local area with a more resilient water network.The new km pipe will carry nearly a million litres of clear, fresh drinking water each day.Scott Fraser, Scottish Waterrsquos Corporate Affairs Regional Manager, said: ldquoThe team has worked incredibly hard to get the traffic management element of these works completed as quickly as possible.ldquoThis pipeline will ensure that customers can continue to enjoy a reliable supply of fresh water long into the future.

title: have-a-cracking-easter-at-traquair
story: A CRACKING good Easter is on the cards at Traquair House next weekend with the annual Easter Eggstravaganza.More than , mini eggs have been hidden in the famous maze.And there will be plenty opportunities to win bigger Easter eggs as well.Catherine Maxwell Stuart, organiser of the event, told us: "The Easter Eggstravaganza is almost an institution at Traquair."We have been running the event since  when very few other Easter egg events were held at visitors attractions."We have refined the event over the year to ensure every child has a great time and everyone leaves with some eggs.But its not just about chocolate at Traquair during Easter as theres plenty more fun throughout the family day.There is a chance to make musical instruments and your very own Easter bonnet to take part in the Easter parade.And new this year is a fairy training workshop where children can brush up on making potions, wishes and spells with the Fairy Godmother.The Easter Eggstravaganza at Traquair takes place on Sunday, April .The grounds open at am with activities starting at noon.There are three egg hunts for under s this year - at .pm the first hunt will be for five-to-six-year-olds in the Maze, at .pm there will be an under fives egg scramble in the Old Walled Garden, and at .pm a hunt for seven-to-nine year olds will be held in the Maze.

title: scottish-chamber-orchestra-tune-up-for-galashiels-performance
story: WITH summer fast approaching, the internationally-renowned Scottish Chamber Orchestraare preparing to embark upon the first leg of their  summer tour across the south of Scotland.And part of the June leg will include a visit to Galashiels.The SCO bring with them an exhilarating programme of popular classics from Mendelssohn, Mozart and Beethoven.SCO Sub-Principal Double Bass, Adrian Bornet describes the Orchestrarsquos summer tours as one of the happiest moments of music making in our yearly calendar as we explore a beautul country and revisit familiar places and audiences.Making his SCO debut this tour is winner of the prestigious  Nestleacute and Salzburg Festival Young Conductors Award, Hungarian conductor Gaacutebor Kaacuteli.He will open the Volunteer Hall concert with Mendelssohnrsquos The Hebrides ndash a work inspired by the th century composerrsquos spectacular journey by steamer from Fort William to Tobermory.Stepping into the spotlight for Mozartrsquos Clarinet Concerto is Spanish clarinettist Maximilliano Martiacuten.Martiacuten is a tour de force, never failing to inspire audiences in his dual career as SCO Principal Clarinet and in-demand international soloist.His effortless phrasing and mellluous tone, demonstrated in celebrated recordings of the clarinet repertoire, are what will make this performance of Mozartrsquos famous Clarinet Concerto magical.The unyielding energy of Beethovenrsquos playful Symphony No  makes for an exhilarating conclusion to the evening.A spokeswoman for the Scottish Chamber Orchestra said: "We are passionate about sharing the experience of exceptional live orchestral music-making and inspiring new generations of classical music lovers."The summer tour supports this mission by making concerts as accessible as possible to younger audiences by offering free tickets to Under s and pound tickets for Under s, students and the unemployed."Tickets for all of the summer tour dates are now on sale.The SCO performs at the Volunteer Hall in Galashiels on Saturday, June  from .pm.Tickets, priced at pound for adults, pound for OAPs, pound for unemployed, students and Under s, and free for Under s, are available from the SCO website ndash www.sco.org.uk

title: galashiels-weight-loss-groups-raise-3k-for-charity
story: Local members of a weight-loss company have raised pound, by donating clothes that no longer fit to charity.The Galashiels Slimming World groups collected  bags of clothes, shoes, homeware and accessories to donate to Cancer Research UK.The initiative aims to raise awareness of how keeping a healthy weight can reduce the risk of developing some types of cancer.Slimmers donated clothes they were confident they wouldnrsquot need again after following a weight-loss plan.Claire Ford, who runs the Galashiels Slimming World groups at Galashiels Rugby Club, said: ldquoI canrsquot quite believe how many bags we managed to collect, and the fact we found some gold ones too, I canrsquot wait to seeany of my members are winners! I knew my members were amazing, but I didnrsquot expect such an incredible level of effort!The fundraising is part of the national campaign Big Golden Slimming World Clothes Throw, which lsquogoes goldrsquo this year for the th birthday of the weight management organisation.The campaign included the chance to win a VIP shopping and makeover experience for anyone who found a golden bag, and the Galashiels group was among the lucky ones.Last year the groups raised a record of poundmillion in two weeks, and since  the partnership has generated more than poundmillion worth of stock.Claire said: ldquoSeeing members donate their too-big clothes is just the cherry on top for me as a Consultant. What I find so special is seeing members transform before my eyes as they lose weight.,params: .pushldquoMany go from shy, apprehensive iniduals who join with their confidence at rock bottom. title: kith-and-kin-with-the-borders-family-history-society
story: Several people have commented to me that they were disappointed that they missed Isabel Gordonrsquos talk on smallpox at the end of March.One person forgot to change the clocks, another had a puncture on the way, another went to our old meeting place in Melrose.They missed a very interesting talk. She started by telling us that her vaccination was in the thigh, as it was for other girls, so that it didnrsquot mar the upper arm, just in case that girl, might later in le, wear a sleeveless evening dress - how thoughtful of the doctor! We learnt that smallpox dates back to before , BC and came from the Middle East, that Pharaoh Rameses V died in , BC of smallpox. Isabel mentioned lots of other people well-known to history who suffered from smallpox or died of it, including Saint Nicasius, Bishop of Rheims, who, though he was decapitated by the invading Vandals in  AD, in the cathedral he founded, picked up his head and walked to the altar, reciting a psalm. He is the patron saint of smallpox victims.It was called smallpox in the th century to dferentiate it from syphilis, which at that time was known as the great pox. It is a crowd disease that passed by inhalation, though can stay active on clothes, blankets and other objects. So the North American Indian tribes, the Aztecs and the Incas were devastated by smallpox, and the native tribes in Canada were infected by missionaries and priests possibly through donations of bedding or clothes. Itrsquos clear that smallpox was a major disease in Europe from at least the th century, killing at least , people each year and leaving visible evidence of the disease on the faces of millions of others. Smallpox seems to have been taken as inevitable right up until the mid-th century in Britain and only a few lucky iniduals came through it, unspoilt. The Chinese had a defence against it, more than , years ago, by blowing powdered smallpox scabs up the noses of healthy people ndash a form of inoculation. Though reports of this practice reached London in , it wasnrsquot accepted by the medical profession and it was almost  years before Edward Jenner demonstrated the effectiveness of using cowpox to protect people from smallpox.Wikipedia lists six th century acts about vaccination, though itrsquos not clear whether they all affected Scotland: in , making it available free of charge in , making it compulsory for every healthy child the ,  and  acts extending the requirement for children to be compulsorily vaccinated the  act while guaranteeing the right of parents to choose whether to have their baby vaccinated, effectively made it very dficult to avoid. Smallpox was declared to be globally eradicated in . Children are no longer vaccinated so they are potentially at risk,it comes back. How can it do that,itrsquos been eradicated  The smallpox virus is stored by several nations, supposedly for research but could potentially be used for biological warfare.Peter Munro

title: elephant-sessions-set-for-galashiels-stampede
story: ONE of Scotlands best traditional bands is heading for Galashiels.Elephant Sessions, who were crowned as  MG Alba Scots Trad Music Awards Live Act of the Year, will bring their legendary live show to the Volunteer Hall next month.The band, who have transformed traditional music and shake the very foundations of expectation, are set to release their new album What Makes You in the next few weeks.Hailing from the Highlands, Elephant Sessions exploded onto the indie folk scene to unparalleled effect with their last album All We Have Is Now.The band have since appeared at some of the worldrsquos most notable venues and festivals with audiences crowd surfing their way through the summer and marquee floors breaking under the weight of bouncing fans. Galashiels looks set to be no dferent.Charting in the French download charts and selling bucket loads across Europe, with praise from the likes of Rolling Stone Magazine, All We Have Is Now firmly established this band as completely unique.What Makes You promises to build on this success and sees the front line of mandolin and fiddle pushing their limits further, matching the percussive rhythm of drums, bass and guitar, whilst fusing with electronic dance beats. This is traditional music turned on its head, a re-invention of expectation, a brand new sound.Mandolin player Alasdair Taylor told us: "We feel like our sound has matured and wersquore playing and writing music that we really want to be playing.ldquoComposing and performing the material from this new album has been so much fun so far and we canrsquot wait to play to Galashiels crowds again and give them a performance to remember.saw awards in abundance. Opening the year as winners of the lsquoAlbum of the Yearrsquo category at the MG Alba Scots Trad Music Awards, they went on to be finalists as Best Group at the BBC Radio  Folk Awards.In May, Belhaven Brewery got together with the band to award the first ever Belhaven Bursary for innovation in music.bursary amount matches the Mercury Music prize and was awarded in recognition of their unique and outstanding sound. It was accompanied by the bands own beer lsquoElephant Sessions Alersquo, which was launched last year.In August, the band also found themselves shortlisted for Scottish Album of the Year ndash an award covering every genre of music from indie, blues and rock to pop, folk and the inidual sound that is Elephant Sessions.Closing  by picking up the coveted Live Band of the Year awardthe band, who met on the Newcastle University Folk Degree, are set to do no less with What Makes You.Elephant Sessions play Galashiels on Friday, May .

title: gala-mens-shed-calls-for-help-from-local-community
story: Galarsquos Menrsquos Shed has appealed to the local community to help it grow.The grouprsquos big plans for the shed require resources, and the members are turning to fellow locals for help.The Menrsquos Shed in Galashiels was one of the first sheds to be set up in the Scottish Borders five years ago and has recently been praised by MSPs in a Parliament debate.Galashiels and District Councillor Euan Jardine visited the menrsquos shed to hear about how the project was going.He said: ldquoIt was great to visit the shed and speak to the members about their exciting plans.ldquoThere is a huge amount of really great wood work being produced, so I would really love to see it on display in a town centre venue. Hopefully we can start to twin with others sheds and start to visit them too, but we would require some transport.Councillor John Greenwell, Scottish Borders Councils Menrsquos Shed Champion added: ldquoMenrsquos sheds are the fastest growing organisation in the Borders, and I am pleased to see my Council colleagues supporting them.ldquoGala shed being one of the first in the Borders has always led the way, so I am particularly pleased to see they have an inclusive policy that allows women to be full members.The works of the local Menrsquos shed are set to be on display as Gala members join five other menrsquos sheds in a play in Musselburgh on th May.

title: alan-keeps-security-in-focus
story: A SELKIRK firm is leading the way in the security sector with its pledge to develop engineers of the future, both within the Scottish Borders and across Scotland.In his role as Scottish Regional Chair for the British Security Industry Association, Alan Wheelans, managing director of Selkirk-based Border Safeguard, attended the Security Skills Challenge at New College Lanarkshire, where one of his apprentice engineers, Lewis Robertson, attends on day release.A total of  third-year Modern Apprentices took part in the Security Skills Challenge at the Kirkintilloch Campus.The main atrium was transformed with a row of ten purpose-built competition booths where trainees had to complete a six-hour challenge to install an intruder and CCTV system.The competition was attended by almost  industry specialists, including representatives from the National Security Inspectorate , who are one of the industry leading bodies.Alan, who himself made the journey from apprentice to company director, aid: ldquoFor us to send Lewis up to Kirkintilloch is a signicant commitment, both by the business and Lewis himself, but it is well worth it. Hersquos not only learning industry essentials but, hersquos bringing back to our business things that hersquos learning from other engineers too.As part of his role with the BSIA, Alan has recently been involved in the reviewing and rewriting of the occupational standards of the SVQ qualication in Installation in Fire and Security Systems for the modern apprenticeship scheme.The opportunity to observe the competition gave Alan the chance to see the learning in practise.Noting the challenges faced by the security sector in recruiting and retaining a highly skilled workforce.Alan added: ldquoWe are now a third-generation family business due to celebrate our th anniversary in ."We are a close-knit team of twenty with  percent of our staff under the age of ."Over the past  years, we have learned the most effective means to ensuring business growth is working with young professionals, teaching them everything they need to know to become highly experienced engineers."Our work with those in education will help not only our business but others in the sector too.

title: rescheduled-closures-for-galafoot-bridge
story: A PLANNED full closure of Galafoot Bridge near Galashiels has been postponed for a week.Contractors working on the A bridge near Kingsnowe roundabout were due to close the full carriageway from pm thisevening.But the closure will now take place on Sunday, April  from pm until am the following morning.With most of the resurfacing work completed, workmen will now improve safety on the parapet system.Over the next few weeks they will be raising the height of the existing parapets.This final stage of the works is due to be completed by Friday, May .Tom Wallace from road contractors Amey, said: ldquoTransport Scotland has held discussions with local stakeholders regarding increased traffic on these footpaths."Amey was subsequently asked to develop a solution for the bridge footpaths, which would improve overall safety while taking into consideration the popularity of these footpaths as viewing s for local events.

title: drumroll-as-bandstand-opens-in-earlston
story: PUPILS at Earlston Primary School have plenty to make a noise about after the opening of their very own bandstand.The project was conducted by Friends of Earlston Primary School.And it attracted major support from BSW Timber, who donated the construction wood, and both Earlston Community Council and Earlston Community Development Trust who provided financial support.The construction work was carried out by Scottish Borders Councils unpaid work team.And this week children from Primary ,  and  joined representatives of the ious groups for a grand opening.A spokeswoman for Friends of Earlston Primary School told us: "Through the generous support of the local organisations we have been able to make a number of improvements to the playground - a key priority identied by parents, and we are delighted with the new features which benefits the childrenrsquos outdoor environment."Everyone agrees the unpaid work team have done an amazing job which is greatly appreciated."As well as providing a space for musical practice, the bandstand offers shelter and the opportunity for outdoor learning.Two giant chalkboards have also been erected in the playground, which are already being put to good use by the children.

title: borders-choc-champion-ruth-set-for-channel-4-series
story: A BORDERS chocolate master is set to appear in a new Channel  series.Ruth Hinks from Cocoa Black in Peebles will feature on Extreme Chocolate Makers ndash which is broadcast to  countries.The programme focuses on dferent elite chocolatiers throughout the -part series.And Ruth will be appearing on the one-hour Easter special where she will be working on a showpiece for the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire of Chatsworth House.The showpiece, which is made of kg of chocolate, tells the story of Boney ndash a Blenheim Spaniel belonging to the th Duke of Devonshire.And the , calorie work of art will be on display at the Derbyshire stately home until October .Ruths second commission for the series is a le-sized chocolate beer barrel.Commissioned by Dougal Sharp, chairman of Edinburgh-based craft brewer, Innis  Gunn, it was smashed open in front of a crowd of more than  at the companys new Taproom bar on Lothian Road in Edinburgh.Ruth told us: "The chance to take part in a global TV series is a dream come true."At Cocoa Black, wersquove pulled out all the stops on what we hope will be mind-blowing television."Something that will resonate with chocolate lovers around the world and bring them to Peebles."The -part series will hit the airwaves at pm on Easter Sunday.The programme is made by the same TV company behind Extreme Cake Makers ndash which won Best Daytime Series at the Broadcast Awards in .

title: winding-back-time-to-when-selkirk-clock-didnt-stop
story: Following recent renovation work on Selkirks iconic town clock, it has been beset by problems.As well as regularly stopping, the four-faced clock has also been seen going backwards.Up until  the clock mechanism and chimes had been maintained and monitored by the Brown family.And for over a century it never stopped.John Brown began maintenance and the daily winding-up of the clock in .The watchmaker and jeweller, who worked out of the family business at the premises on the corner of Tower Street now occupied by the Red Cross, passed the baton to his son Tom.And likewise the maintenance and winding-up duties were passed to his son Jack.The Brown familys century-long involvement came to an end in  when Jack retired.His daughter, Margaret Smith, recalls: "The clock was wound up every Monday morning at am."I often went up the tower with my dad - you had to time your jump to avoid the pendulum on your way to the mechanism."It had to be wound up four times on each visit, once for each clock face."Although the mechanism rarely ever showed any signs of faltering, Margarets father, like his father and grandfather, would position himself next tot he mechanism every Hogmanay and Common Riding to provide manual back-up in case the chimes didnt sound.Margaret added: "With all the problems we have just now with the clock people stop me to askI know whats going on."Its a dferent mechanism from the one my father, grandfather and great-grandfather looked after, so Im not sure what the problem is."

title: defence-secretary-does-not-like-idea-of-legal-aid-for-is-bride-shamima-begum

title: down memory lane march 29 2019
story: It is packed with historical and contemporary stories and some tasters are printed below:Open water swimmer Mercedes Gleitze, who attempted to swim the North Channel and was the first woman to swim the English Channel features on the front page.Angus Martin, the magazine#s editor, has reviewed a -page book about her exploits.Swimming was not her only accomplishment and Mercedes was a notable charity worker.Mr Martin quotes her as saying: #I know of no sensation but that of calm pleasure at the prospect of another tussle with those #calling# waves. When one loves one is not afraid.#A tattered notebook of Gaelic poetry, by Kintyre#s Anna NicFhearghais was deposited with the National Library of Scotland  years ago.It forms the basis for a seven-page essay investigation into the poet#s roots.The study by Dr Anne Macleod Hill, digging into census records and family history, discusses the era and context in which Ms NicFhearghais set down her poetry the end of the th century.A th-century distiller, John Ross, known for his #wit and racy anecdotes# and hailed as #perhaps the greatest# in the history of Campbeltown, features in an extract from a forthcoming book.Page  features a conversation, which may have been imagined, between interviewer, art historian and journalist, Edward Pinnington and animal artist, Sir George Pirie.The text tells us Pirie had a Kintyre connection and in a footnote Mr Martin explains he was born in Longrow and that Pinnington#s interview appeared in The Art Journal .Another investigation of paintings by Archibald MacKinnon, by Mr Martin, follows on page  and this leads into an appreciation of #Jamie Morrison: Wandering Packman# a local worthy painted by MacKinnon and displayed in .A history of the Macharioch Memorial Cross by Murdo MacDonald describes a December  mini-tour of Southend led by #an enthusiastic Elizabeth Marrison on her home turf#.Mr Martin#s regular #By Hill and title: highlands and islands link for liveargyll members
story: The partnership allows LiveArgyll members to access gyms, public swimming and fitness classes at leisure facilities across the Highland Region, Moray, The Western Isles and Orkney at no extra cost.The scheme, involving the four other areas, will be known as the Leisure Link Partnership .Believed to be the first of its type in Scotland, the LLP means that when working away from home or on holiday, members from participating areas can, at no extra cost, use the local facilities as part of their existing home-based membership.Chair of Community Leisure UK and High Le Highland chief executive, Ian Murray, said: #I am delighted to see the LLP come to fruition as we have been working on this project for some time with colleagues in Moray, The Western Isles, Orkney and Argyll and Bute.#We are constantly looking for ways to widen the services offered to High Le members.#The LLP is a major step forward enabling them and their family the flexibility to use their cards at one of the partnership sites, and most importantly…at no extra cost.#We are also pleased to have initiated what we understand to be the first ever multi-area reciprocal card scheme in Scotland.#Although the initial participants in the partnership are across the north of Scotland, we are in ongoing discussions with other areas in Scotland, as well as in both Northern Ireland and Wales which have also adopted the High Le model across their own culture and leisure services.#So we are hopeful that the LLP may soon be available further afield.#Kevin Anderson, general manager of LiveArgyll, said: #We are delighted to be part of this new partnership which is an exciting addition to the new LiveArgyll low-cost membership structure launched on April .#We look forward to welcoming visitors from the four areas to our fantastic facilities.#Further information can be found on the LiveArgyll website www.liveargyll

title: letter whats it really like caring for a loved one
story: More than , people in Scotland are caring unpaid for a loved one who is older, disabled, or seriously ill.Whether it’s round-the-clock or for a few hours a week, in their own home or for someone at the other end of a motorway – caring can have a huge impact on people’s lives.Unpaid carers are holding families together and enabling loved ones to get the most out of le.They make an enormous contribution to society and together save the UK economy £ billion a year.Yet many find themselves stretched to the limit often financially, without access to support or unable to take a break.Carers in Scotland deserve to have their say on what affects them and their ability to care – what is working well and what needs to change.By filling in Carers UK’s State of Caring survey, at www.carerscotland.org they can help inform the Scotland’s most comprehensive research into experiences of looking after a loved one.The survey answers will help the charity make le better for carers.They will give us the evidence to push carers up the agenda for policy makers and politicians and campaign for support and change.It has never been more important for unpaid carers to share their experiences.Simon Hodgson,Director of Carers Scotland.

title: thought for the week april 5 2019
story: One was a peasant procession, the other an imperial procession.From the east Jesus rode a donkey down the Mount of Olives, cheered by his followers – a ragged, but enthusiastic band.Jesus was from the peasant village of Nazareth, his message was about the kingdom of God, and his followers came from the peasant class.On the opposite side of the city from the west, Pontius Pilate, the Roman governor of Judea and Samaria, entered Jerusalem at the head of a column of imperial cavalry and soldiers.Jesus# procession proclaimed the kingdom of God Pilate#s proclaimed the power of the empire.Imagine the imperial procession arriving in the city.It would be a visual manestation of power: cavalry on horseback, foot soldiers, leather armour, helmets, weapons, banners, golden eagle standards mounted on poles and flags fluttering in the breeze of authority.Listen to the sounds: the marching of boots, the creaking of leather, the clinking of bridles, the beating of drums, the sound of authority.Pilate#s procession displayed not only imperial power, but also Roman imperial theology.And according to this theology, the emperor was not simply the ruler of Rome, but the Son of God.Here was a conflictever there was one.Jesus# procession deliberately countered what was happening on the other side of the city.Pilate#s procession embodied the power, the glory and violence of the empire that ruled the world.Jesus# procession embodied an alternative vision, the kingdom of God and the power of love.Rome proclaimed the love of power.People were joining the processions.Which procession will you follow

title: retired teacher unearths marquis family roots
story: A retired teacher, from Leicestershire, Steve Marquis, has researched his family’s colourful past and unearthed claimed links with Flora MacDonald.The Marquis family history also includes the Jacobite rebellions and Tarbert, Loch Fyne, where his forebears lived for more than three centuries.His grandfather, Angus Marquis, born in Tarbert in , was descended from a long line of Loch Fyne fishermen. He left the village for an apprenticeship at Govan shipyards during the First World War before heading south for Leicester in the s.Steve, , one of several Marquises still living in Leicestershire, has just published The Le and Times of The Marquis Family of Argyll.It covers the family’s long Highland history as bards, smugglers, clan warriors, rebels and fishermen, with one forebear being tacksman on the island of Cara.He was inspired by his grandparents’ lives as exiled Scots, and their tales of Highland le.Though Angus Marquis left Tarbert for a new le in the south nearly a century ago, his children and grandchildren still make summer ‘pilgrimages’ to the family’s spiritual home, tracing the buildings where the Marquises lived and their graves in Tarbert cemetery.‘It has been an interesting experience,’ said Steve. ‘I have been helped in my research by many people and have unearthed details we simply didn’t know about the Marquises who went before us.#There was always an assumption that we were Huguenots, but that appears not to be the case. We were Gaelic speakers whose roots lie deep in Scottish soil.#I discovered that we were linked to Flora MacDonald through marriage, and that our bardic traditions go right back to the s.’Until the late th century, the Marquises were known as MacMarcuis or MacMarquis, and had strong links with the MacDonalds.Angus Marquis was one of the seven children of fisherman Dugald Marquis, born in , who fathered five children by his first we, Margaret Bain, and two # including Angus # by his second, Mary McLeod.While an apprentice in Glasgow, Angus met his future we, Mary Jordan, from Furnace. Together they had five sons, including Steve’s father, George.While several of their offspring now live in America, Australia and Cornwall, most of the Marquis family settled in Leicestershire.The book is available from Steve at: stephen.marquis@ntlworld and there is a website: www.marquisfamilyhistory.
